surprisingly stretchy cast-on why this cast-on there are plenty of other cast-ons out there if you want an alternative but my main reason for picking the jssc for this pattern is that as the name implies it is surprisingly stretchy if you decide to switch it out for another one make sure that the cast-on edge is still sufficiently stretchy to not cinch around the little one s legs jssc is essentially just a row of slipknots and will not make the most discrete edge possible but it blends nicely into a 1x1 rib things to be aware of with the jssc this cast-on will produce a very stretchy cast-on edge but it doesn t feel very stretchy as you re knitting the first row this is because the yarn does not move freely between the stitches and the inter-stitch stretches this is why it is so important to make sure that the stitches are sitting close together because they will keep the same distance and if some of them are further apart your cast-on edge will get a little loop or bump in that place it is also why the pattern tells you to knit one row before joining in the round this is just to make your life a bit easier as that first row will be a little bit stiff to knit still confused there are plenty of resources available online for jeny s surprisingly stretchy cast-on both photos with text and video you can find a brief video in my instagram highlights search for @lillalin_ and then click the highlight called two little feet but the one that was my own favorite when learning this cast-on was a blog post by talena winters which features both video and photo
